The INFO :
:
Disappearances
Q&A w/ Director Jay Craven Tuesday, July 10 following the 7:30pm screening

This picaresque ?western? set in Kingdom County Vermont has a great cast that includes a grizzled Kris Kristofferson, a spooky Genevieve Bujold, a wily Gary Farmer and a loathsome Lothaire Bluteau. Visually the film exposes a hard-scrabble universe of gut-wrenching hard work and ruined dreams, but set against breath-takingly beautiful scenery with virgin woods and clear streams. One who?s not willing to ruin a dream, Quebec Bill (Kristofferson) leads a little army out of northern Vermont in 1932 to steal a notorious smuggler?s cache of whiskey and return it to the US?for Bill?s own profit of course. Enlisting his brother-in-law?s white Cadillac for speed and durability and taking his young teen son Wild Bill (a misnomer) along for the experience. Quebec Bill?s adventures are often punctuated by magical realism and Wild Bill?s by many firsts?first time drunk and first kill among them. Chasing them for his liquor is Carcajou, a French Canadian bandit played by Bluteau, dressed in a civil war uniform that looks more like a costume than clothes. It?s all a wonderful time, often sweet and comical. Vermont director Jay Craven made the film for $1.7 million but the money went far in the obvious places. The look and feel of the film is as rich as its characters. (US, 2006) 103 min.

Hartford Courant review can be found here: http://www.courant.co...
